name: ferroniobium production, from pyrochlore concentrate, 66% Nb | ferroniobium, 66% Nb | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/25049/documentation

This dataset refers to the production of ferroniobium from refined pyrochlore concentrate, 63% Nb2O5 (produced from the mining and beneficiation activities in Araxa, Brazil) through the aluminothermic reduction process in Araxa, Brazil. This dataset is based mostly on the following source: Eckert J (2012) Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In: Ullmann’s Encyclopedia of industrial chemistry. Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &Co.KGaA (for more information check the sampling procedure). 

The activities start with the processing of the refined pyrochlore concentrate (63% Nb2O5) in the metallurgy unit.

The activities end with the production of Ferroniobium product, 66% Nb.

No allocation is applied.
category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data are considered representative of current production practices.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The Araxa carbonatite complex in Brasil is located about 6 km south of the city of Araxa in the state of Minas Gerais and serves as the largest known niobium reserve in the world. Since the 1960s, the complex has been mined by CBMM (Companhia Brasileira de Metalurgia e Mineracao), being responsible today for more than 80% of the global niobium production, including ferroniobium.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The refined pyrochlore concentrate is placed in the metallurgical unit, where it is mixed with aluminium powder and iron, homogenized and processed in electric furnaces (as reported by Eckert 2012) in order to produce Ferroniobium via aluminothermic reduction (in electric arc furnaces) with the following chemical reaction: 3Nb2O5 + 10Al -> 6Nb + 5Al2O3;The aluminothermic reaction is not self-sustaining (enthalpy of this reaction: − 276.1 kJ/mol Al), meaning that preheating or addition of compounds (such as BaO2, CaO2, KClO4, KClO3 or NaNO3) into the mixture that release oxygen is required. Furthermore, the CBMM Ferroniobium production process requires primary aluminium powder while the added iron (or iron oxide) is secondary (scrap). It is reported by Eckert (see source above) that such a process requires 18 t of pyrochlore concentrate and yields 11 t of FeNb product and approximately 20 t of slag. Afterwards the FeNb block product from the reaction is detached from the slag and solidifies while the slag is disposed in the tailings dam. Finally, the product is cooled, crushed in the required size and sent to the customers.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
This dataset is based on the following source: Albrecht, S., Cymorek, C. and Eckert, J. (2011). Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, (Ed.). https://doi.org/10.1002/14356007.a17_251.pub2. The inputs / outputs considered for the aluminothermic reduction process (inputs: pyrochlore concentrate, iron oxide as scrap, aluminium powder, fluorspar, lime / outputs: slag) were taken from the abovementioned source. The amount of slag produced is based on wet mass balance and the original amount reported from the abovementioned source was not considered, leading to an underestimation of the amount of the produced slag (1.61 kg compared to 1.82 kg per kg of produced FeNb). Furthermore, the amount of pure niobium oxide produced as byproduct (0.1363 kg per kg of FeNb) is not containted in the abovementioned source (even though its existence its acknowledged by the authors) and is based on the following source: Alves, A. R., & Coutinho, A. d. R. (2019). Life cycle assessment of niobium: A mining and production case study in Brazil. Minerals Engineering, 132, 275-283. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mineng.2018.11.041.
Due to lack of data about the electricity consumption, the electricity required for the aluminothermic process was taken from this source: http://heattreatconsortium.com/metals-advisor/electric-arc-furnace/electric-arc-furnace-energy-consumption/. Particulate matter emissions exists according  to the following source but no specific amounts are reported (Alves, A. R., & Coutinho, A. d. R. (2019). Life cycle assessment of niobium: A mining and production case study in Brazil. Minerals Engineering, 132, 275-283. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mineng.2018.11.041. Due to lack of data, the amount of PM is based on the following source (https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/2-industrial-processes/2-c-metal-production/2-c-2-ferroalloys-production/view) which provides a simplified process description for the estimation of emissions of ferroalloys, including FeNb. 
The infrastructural input (non-ferrous metal smelter) was based on the supplementary materials of the following publication: Nuss, P., & Eckelman, M. J. (2014). Life Cycle Assessment of Metals: A Scientific Synthesis. PLOS ONE, 9(7), e101298. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0101298.
The electrode exchange (proxy with anode) is based on the following source: Dolganova, I., Bosch, F., Bach, V., Baitz, M., & Finkbeiner, M. (2020). Life cycle assessment of ferro niobium. The International Journal of Life Cycle Assessment, 25(3), 611-619. doi:10.1007/s11367-019-01714-7.
For more details about the considered exchanges, consult the individual exchanges comments.

flow.name: ferroniobium, 66% Nb
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/24:Manufacture of basic metals/241:Manufacture of basic iron and steel/2410:Manufacture of basic iron and steel

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of refined pyrochlore concentrate required for the production of 1 kg of ferroniobium (FeNb). The amount is based on the following source: Eckert J (2012) Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In: Ullmann’s
Encyclopedia of industrial chemistry. Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH
& Co.KGaA. In the abovementioned source, a concentrate with 60% Nb2O5 content was considered. Since the newest data (Source: ) suggest that 1.55 kg of refined pyrochlore concentrate with 63% Nb2O5 content is required for the production of 1 kg of FeNb, the original value is replaced with 1.55 kg. Furthermore, this adjustment holds true, considering that in the end the same mass of Nb2O5 content is processed for the production of 1 kg of FeNb (1.636 *0.60 ≈ 1.55*0.63).

exchanges.description:
The amount of partculate emissions is not contained on the source, on which this dataset is based on (Source: Eckert J (2012) Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In: Ullmann’s
Encyclopedia of industrial chemistry. Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH
& Co.KGaA). However the emission of Particulate Matter (PM) exists according  to the following source (Alves, A. R., & Coutinho, A. d. R. (2019). Life cycle assessment of niobium: A mining and production case study in Brazil. Minerals Engineering, 132, 275-283. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mineng.2018.11.041. Due to lack of data, the amount of PM is based on the following source (https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/2-industrial-processes/2-c-metal-production/2-c-2-ferroalloys-production/view) which provides a simplified process description for the estimation of emissions of ferroalloys. The amount of PM>10 um is calculated by subtracting the amount of PM10  from the amount of TSP (total suspended solids). TSP = 1000 g / Mg alloy produced PM10 = 850 g / Mg alloy produced. Value adjusted to correspond to kg per kg of alloy produced.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 10 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: The amount of electricity required for the aluminothermic processing is assumed to be 0.475 kWh (Source: http://heattreatconsortium.com/metals-advisor/electric-arc-furnace/electric-arc-furnace-energy-consumption/).

& Co.KGaA). However the emission of Particulate Matter (PM) exists according  to the following source (Alves, A. R., & Coutinho, A. d. R. (2019). Life cycle assessment of niobium: A mining and production case study in Brazil. Minerals Engineering, 132, 275-283. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mineng.2018.11.041. Due to lack of data, the amount of PM is based on the following source (https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/2-industrial-processes/2-c-metal-production/2-c-2-ferroalloys-production/view) which provides a simplified process description for the estimation of emissions of ferroalloys. exchanges.description:
The amount of partculate emissions is not contained on the source, on which this dataset is based on (Source: Eckert J (2012) Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In: Ullmann’s
Encyclopedia of industrial chemistry. Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH
& Co.KGaA). However the emission of Particulate Matter (PM) exists according  to the following source (Alves, A. R., & Coutinho, A. d. R. (2019). Life cycle assessment of niobium: A mining and production case study in Brazil. Minerals Engineering, 132, 275-283. doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.mineng.2018.11.041. Due to lack of data, the amount of PM is based on the following source (https://www.eea.europa.eu/publications/emep-eea-guidebook-2019/part-b-sectoral-guidance-chapters/2-industrial-processes/2-c-metal-production/2-c-2-ferroalloys-production/view) which provides a simplified process description for the estimation of emissions of ferroalloys. The amount of PM,>2.5 um and < 10 um is calculated by subtracting the amount of PM2.5  from the amount of PM10. PM10 = 850 g / Mg alloy produced PM2.5 = 600 g / Mg alloy produced. Value adjusted to correspond to kg per kg of alloy produced.

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of iron oxide required for the production of 1 kg of ferroniobium (FeNb). The amount is based on the following source: Eckert J (2012) Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In: Ullmann’s
Encyclopedia of industrial chemistry. Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH
& Co.KGaA. The CBMM production process utilizes iron scrap, which is taken into account.

exchanges.description:
This exchange represents the amount of slag produced as a byproduct during the production of 1 kg of ferroniobium (FeNb). The amount presented here is based on wet mass balance and is an underestimated value compared to the one reported on the following source (20000 kg of slag for the production of 11000 kg of FeNb or 1.82 kg of slag for the production of 1 kg of FeNb): Eckert J (2012) Niobium and Niobium Compounds. In: Ullmann’s
Encyclopedia of industrial chemistry. Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH
& Co.KGaA. This exchange is considered as a proxy for the produced slag, because the refined concentrate is process in an electric arc furnace (see general comment).
